statement: Given triangle ABC with circumcircle Γ and incentre I, the incircle touches sides BC, CA, AB at D, E, F respectively. Let K be the intersection of AI with Γ again. Prove that the line DK is tangent to Γ.
Let p be a prime number. Prove that there exists a prime number q such that for every integer n, the number n^p − n is divisible by q.
Let x₁, x₂, … , xₙ be real numbers such that x₁ + x₂ + ··· + xₙ = 0 and x₁² + x₂² + ··· + xₙ² = 1. Prove that max(x₁, x₂, … , xₙ) ≥ 1 / √(n − 1).
In triangle ABC, the bisector of angle A meets side BC at D. The circumcircle of triangle ABD meets AC again at E. Prove that DE is tangent to the circumcircle of triangle ACD.
In a group of n people, each pair of people are either friends or enemies. Prove that there exists a person such that the number of his friends is at least the number of his enemies.

Let a₁, a₂, … be an infinite sequence of integers satisfying 1 ≤ aⱼ ≤ 1997 for all j ≥ 1 and aₖ + k ≠ aₗ + l for all 1 ≤ k < l. Prove that there exist positive integers b and N such that |∑_{j=m+1}^{n} (aⱼ − b)| ≤ 1000 for all integers m and n with n > m > N.
